title.narrative: TYPHOON HAIYAN - Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: Affected families in priority evacuation centers, relocation sites and communities including affected children in priority schools, day care centres, and temporary learning sites have access to safe and secure basic sanitation and safe water facilities with improved hygiene behaviour and contributes to reducing risk and strengthening resilience., which contributes to Sanitation, Wash And Emergencies, Water. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By the end of the country program, increased access to high-impact preventive services for pregnant women, newborns and children and household behavior change interventions (focused on skilled birth attendance & newborn/ child care, nutrition, Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) and HIV) for resource-challenged vulnerable LGUs with high incidence of child mortality (selected regions with <50 per cent SBA coverage and >31 per cent underweight) and HIV (selected high incidence LGUS with high-risk youth groups), Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) (selected LGUs with <45 per cent sanitation coverage) through strengthen local decentralized health systems and at the same time building resilience as well as advocating for upstream policy changes.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Affected families in priority evacuation centers, relocation sites and communities including affected children in priority schools,day care centres, and temporary learning sites have access to safe and secure basic sanitation and safe water facilities withimproved hygiene behaviour; and contributes to reducing risk and strengthening resilience.

description.narrative: Implementation of the water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) Typhoon Haiyan recovery programme ends, exceeding planned targets and offering lessons for ongoing and future implementation of the Phased Approach to Total Sanitation (PhATS). Commitment was built to ensure continued PhATS implementation through municipal, provincial and regional government programming. | Status:Met | As-of Date:10/01/2017
